content.description: This super unique not-quite-offwidth not-quite-chimney style boulder will certainly keep you on your toes. Start on the hold bottom right arret then use a series of pressure moves and a few crimps to pull your self to the thick root marking the top of the climb. It is possible to top out though not recommended due to the relatively cramped nature of the climb.
content.protection: slight runout towards the start very cramped in the middle, good to have a spotter and some thin mats or pillows for this one
content.location: The largest crack (more than a foot wide at the base) in the whole ledge. About 10/15 feet left of center looking head on.

content.description: Start below the lower horizontal crack on the the larger crimp crouching and smearing, pull out to the right then up to the jugs (cracks).

A long traverse starting in the large lower horizontal crack as far to the right/east as you can start (where the ledge is only about 5 feet high) all the way to Don't Jug Me then up! The lak of feet + overhang for the first 10 feet or so make this a difficult problem.
content.protection: at least 1 mat, 1 spotter, slight runout
content.location: Look all the way to the right of the ledge

content.description: Are you a slab fiend? Try out this killer traverse. Work you way from the left arret of The Trees Are Lava, left across the granite slab. Work your way up and to the left to top out and walk off.
content.location: Start on the left arret of The Trees are Lava.

content.description: Start on the first jug in the lower horizontal crack reach to the second! Good warm up to get used to this rock.
content.location: Just to the right of Little Bear Crack

content.description: A shady granite ledge about 12 feet high at the highest and about 60-70 feet long. Needs serious cleaning and has a bit of a runout in some areas, but nonetheless shows massive potential. WARNING: the hottest of summer days mid JULY-AUG can see this area quite prone to hornet/wasps, PLEASE exercise caution.Because this area sees virtually no action aside from a very limited number of people each year, the top outs are EXTREMELY mossy and need to be cleaned if you plan on topping out. Otherwise bring multiple mats and plan on downclimbing your sends.
